text: hey everyone so I just finished the most
amazing book called the help now to be
fair this is a book that I have read
five or six times but the reason why I
keep returning to this book is because
it's just an amazing story so if you're
anything like me every time you reread a
book
you pick out something different each
time but the one theme that always stuck
out to me every time I read this book is
that they talk about food they talk
about minis chocolate pie they talked
about Maties caramel cake and they talk
about minis Fried Chicken so at the end
of the day when I finish the book I end
up leaving hungry so I always wondered
what does minis cooking really taste
like so today I'm going to share with
you my version of minis caramel cake
okay to start minis caramel cake we are
starting with one and a half sticks of
butter one and a half cups of granulated
sugar 4 eggs one and a half cups of cake
flour two and a half teaspoons of baking
powder half a teaspoon of salt one
tablespoon of pure vanilla extract and
one cup of buttermilk first step go
ahead and mix all your dry ingredients
together add your baking powder and your
salt to your flour then go ahead and
whisk whisk whisk make sure there's no
lumps in there and then go ahead and set
it off to the side okay now it's time to
cream your butter and your sugar
together now I happen to use a hand
mixer here but you can go ahead and use
a stand mixer if you prefer that
[Music]
okay once you have your butter and your
sugar pretty well mixed you can start
adding your eggs one at a time making
sure to mix really well after each
addition and egg number two and mix well
and we have egg number three make sure
you don't get any shells in there like I
did I have to apologize for the shaky
camera I didn't realize how how strong I
was when I was actually mixing the the
cake mixture together and finally the
last egg
[Music]
okay now that the eggs are fully
incorporated we're going to add the
flour and we're going to add this in
three separate additions there's a first
one and then I went ahead and added my
vanilla extract to the buttermilk right
now then go ahead and add half the
bottom up to the mixture and for the
second addition of the flour
and the rest of the buttermilk
and now for the rest of the flour
mixture
now I like to stop right before this
entire mixture is mixed because I like
to finish it off with a plastic scraper
just so that I don't over the mitt over
mix the cake batter too much so it
doesn't come out tough
[Music]
all right so for these cakes I'm using
two 9-inch cake pans so we're gonna prep
them a little bit and I'm just taking a
little bit of cooking spray spritzing a
little bit and then we're going to cover
the bottom with a little bit of
parchment paper and I'm going to show
you a trick that I learned from culinary
school so we're going to take a sheet of
parchment paper and we're gonna fold it
in half lengthwise now you see where the
seam is we're gonna turn it 90 degrees
and then fold it again it's almost like
culinary origami make a sharp crease see
where the seam is flip it over and fold
that crease up towards the edge
they're going to take this piece with
that crease turn it over and then fold
it up
okay then you're gonna take a pair of
scissors and line the point up with the
middle of the cake pan and then find the
edge and you're gonna cut it at a slight
curve at the top and then open it up and
you have the bottom of your cake pan
it's kind of like when you used to make
snowflakes in elementary school this way
I find that I don't need to flour the
cake pan and second one done now I just
eyeball this so just divide the cake
batter into both pans
and just spread it as evenly as possible
all right but these in a 350-degree oven
and we're gonna bake them from anywhere
from 35 to 40 minutes but it depends on
your oven just make sure they spring
back to the touch now that the cakes are
safely baking we can turn our attention
to the caramel we're going to start off
with 3/4 cup of sugar 3 and 3/4 cup of
sugar 1 and 1/2 tablespoons of flour 3/4
of a teaspoon of salt one and a half
tablespoons of pure vanilla extract we
have two sticks plus one tablespoon of
butter and we have 12 ounces of
evaporated milk we're going to start off
caramelizing the 3/4 cup of sugar now
what I'm doing here is making a dry
caramel now normally you don't really
want to stir sugar while it's
caramelizing because there is a risk of
care of crystallizing it but here I'm
not too worried about it we're just kind
of making a nice amber color to caramel
to add to the other mixture
[Music]
and I keep staring it because this is
something you definitely don't want to
walk away from because it can easily
burn so keep it moving
and as you can see it's turning a nice
golden color
[Music]
now as you can see all of sugar has
melted and it's a really gorgeous amber
color and from here we're gonna go ahead
and set it aside and work on our other
mixture okay now the second part to our
caramel is fairly simple we're just
going to throw everything in this pot
and let it come to a boil first we're
going to add our three and
three-quarters cup of sugar our twelve
ounces of our evaporated milk the two
sticks plus one tablespoon of butter
one and a half tablespoons of flour and
a three-quarters of a teaspoon of salt
now you want to make sure to mix this
and incorporate everything because you
don't want that sugar to burn you just
let it melt and as you can see most of
the butter has melted and so at this
point we're going to add the reserved
sugar that we caramelized earlier now
this sugar milk mixture just adds a
really nice golden and dark rich color
to this caramel now this caramel icing
recipe isn't mine I actually found it

just simply the best one we're gonna
give it a little bit of a stir make sure
it's all incorporated and then we're
gonna put a candy thermometer on the
side because we're gonna be cooking this
recipe to 232 degrees Fahrenheit or
softball stage
you'll notice as the caramels cooking
that I continually like to stir it
because I like to keep it moving because
the first time I made it I burned it
pretty badly on the bottom so I learned
that you do kind of have to keep this
caramel moving in order for it to just
have a really great texture

now we're gonna paddle the camel until

but it'll just take a little bit longer
and you're gonna be a little bit more
patient and how great is that texture
this is about ten minutes later and it
kind of looks like peanut butter
fabulous and next up is decorating and I
like to slather a little bit of the

kind of it kind of acts like glue and
just like any cake add a little bit to
the center and second layer now you want
to be a little bit gingerly when your
frosting this cake because I found that
this this icing is pretty heavy and so
it does have a tendency to kind of tear

there
